comments.commentBody:
You believe this: "It is true that imposing draconian requirements on the poor is not about punishment"? Because punishment and blame is what our welfare policy has always been about.

Real public assistance would really assist people, give them chances in life, not hand out niggardly benefits designed to prevent the poor from dying on the streets.

Real public assistance would begin with employers. It would make policy reflect the needs and the dignity of workers. It would make certain jobs exist.

Real public assistance would recognize that anyone could need help. Abandoned by for-maximum-profit insurance-based healthcare, or by some corporation out to maximize next week's profits at the expense of life-long employees, people get into dire circumstances. Ungrudging, reliable social support would rush them back onto their feet .

In the 90s I was an activist in NYC. Chained myself to desks in Albany and all. The debate at the time was forcing people to work for benefits. Conservatives argued that welfare made people benefit-sucking zombies.
Stories flowed about Cadillacs, idleness, lobster. The up-shot was that 'these people' had no incentive to work, and Republicans were going to 'help them' off welfare.

I returned to Manhattan and the renovated Plaza to see at six in the chilly morning a line three blocks long of people so hungry to work they were competing for demeaning, low paying jobs as housekeepers. People who deserve better than we have ever provided them.

Boiling it down to it's ugly residue, the puppets of the tippy top, Walker among many, always want to move decision making away from experts (who know what they are up to) and towards state and local officials who can more easily be manipulated or bought. Wealth and the worry free life of entitlement remain the only goals of those who have absconded with the treasure of the nation. The rest is lies, deceptions, emotional appeals, and now a huge dollop of righteous anger. That anger looks for others to blame for the sad, bleak, state the Bentley class has engineered for the rural, dispossessed 35%.  They are right to be angry for all the good it will do them. Better to get educated in critical thinking, compassion, and gratitude. Things could get a lot worse if we pointy-headed PhDs ridicule and abandon those folks already abused by the tippy top. They are not deplorable, but they are lamentable. Injustice for one spreads to injustice for all. Hopefully, we awake in time.

Mr. Walker does not want to return power to the states.  He wants to give it away to insurance companies that have a vested interest in seeing health care costs soar ever faster.  He wants to give it away to Big Pharma that believes it should be able to gouge consumers and the Medicare and Medicaid healthcare systems - a strategy that has also brought us the current opioid epidemic with its wave of crime and violence.  It is a strategy that marks Mr. Walker as a prime supporter of the drug cartels that have stalked our southern border for years and are now reaching into communities across the country.  Mr. Walker would cede power to whoever has the money to buy his loyalty.  He envisions a country much like France in 1750 where only the poor and middle class paid taxes - the Nobles, aka the rich, and the church that slavishly supported the Nobles, paid no taxes.  It's a beautiful vision of the future that Mr. Walker has - if you are not going to be one of his serfs.

Amy, I hope that your terminal diagnosis is wrong. My mother was diagnosed with stage IV ovarian cancer nearly 10 years ago. She went through the gauntlet, surgery, chemo, rehab. It wasn't easy. In fact she has had to face her mortality from this insidious disease three times. After her third occurrence, she's still here two years later, fighting onward. Don't give up.
Please stop with the "don't give up" garbage. Medicine doesn't heal the soul.

This is to Mary ANC.

WHAT is wrong with you? AI Onion CA 's mother has survived the same condition that is affecting Ms Rosenthal. So he /she has every right to tell Amy to not give up. Medicine CAN save souls, when the physical Body is healed it can heal the soul. Seems like all you want Amy to do is cure up and wait placidly till the end. No, If she wishes, she can keep on hoping and fight to be alive. Nothing wrong there. It is mean to call such sentiment "garbage". Shame on you!
How amazing it must be to experience life in the way that you do. I'm gratefully in awe! Bless you for the inspiration!

"I'd like to find myself a husband."
"Honey, why don't you find a nice single guy and leave the husbands alone?"
==Mae West
I think this is one of the beautiful, moving articles I've read in my life. Thank you.

As a fellow teacher, I wish that our union took more action at the national level to protect our pay and living standards.  If teaching can't pay enough for a teacher to provide a decent standard of living for their kids, no high quality professionals will want to teach.

Our governor is a coward who has been hiding from constituents since his first days in office. He only meets with pre-screened constituents, unless they are on a factory floor where the business owner is a Walker supporter and everyone is intimidated. For Walker to lecture anyone about facing constituents is ludicrous.

Our Senator Collins also only meets privately with pre-screened constituents.  no town hall meeting for her.  "private meetings are more effective".  Don't be fooled by her sudden independence... just show.

Sometime state elections reflect the patriotic if not the racial history of the state, inadequate education, good old boys standards of living, the gentrified in control and the list goes on. Too bad for them....too bad for us as a nation.

C'mon, Ginger, give the guy a break. If your enemies had threatened to murder you, I'll bet that you would take similar measures, maybe even conceal and carry a loaded one.  There's nothing like a death threat to jar one's perception of his/her vulnerability.

I admit that, at first, the cynic in me thought you might be a little starry-eyed about your Jason. But then I thought, that is exactly how we all want to be seen by the people we love. Every single one of us hopes/wishes for someone to see the very best we have to offer - and maybe rose colored glasses are not such a bad thing in a marriage. Jason is very lucky to know you. Seen through your eyes, he sounds pretty wonderful indeed. Thank you for sharing this love letter with us.

Of course it's starry-eyed, and yes, that's how we all see those we love and hope to be seen by those who love us.  And it makes everything better.  I know I see my husband differently than others do, as he does me.  We make each other better and stronger.  That's how it should be.  It's no less accurate - we know the worst of each other, but it matters so little set against the best.  I'd wish that everyone could have a love like this - the world would undoubtedly be a better place.

This is an incredibly poignant piece of writing. It was truly emotional to read.

The most poignant, sad "Modern Love" was written published on 2/26/2006.

"Now I Need To Hide My Love Away" by Ann Hood.

I still cry every time I read this incredibly sad story that I relate to as a parent and as Beatles fan who matches up my trivial life events with their music.
My thoughts and prayers are with Amy, Jason, and the rest of the Rosenthal family.

My thoughts and prayers are also with Ann Ford and her family and

A special thought and prayer for Grace Hood.

Walker makes the same mistake the Democratic campaign made in 2016: mistaking genuine anger for the old left-right power struggle.  No, the angry crowds are not all irresponsible trouble-makers vested in some left-wing agenda.  They tend to be the little people--the marginalized--about whom the current GOP cares little.  All the old trickle-down arguments are being hauled out and pumped up: tax cuts for the wealthy will bring slews of new jobs, and so on, when the beneficiaries will actually use the extra revenue not to create jobs (demand does that) but for mergers and acquisitions, the fun games of the one percent.

I see that 523 people recommend this comment and it is a NYT Pick.
I think the tone of this is totally inappropriate to the story that is being written.
A classless response that pushes an agenda instead of supporting the people who are suffering.

Some other issues that should not be left to State level: gay marriage, as it impacts Federal laws and regulations on rights between married adults; pollution, as one state's lax laws causes another state's headaches; education (for the same reasons you gave about healthcare); housing (for the same reasons you gave about healthcare); etc., etc.

In fact, there are very few things that should be left to the state level.

In f

An educated and informed citizenry is the heart of any democracy. Scott Walker has been at war with the University of Wisconsin from the get-go, attempting in ways large and small to eviscerate it. Like many of his GOP cronies, Walker thrives when the citizenry becomes dumbed-down. Just as microbes proliferate in the dark. Welcome to America under the education president NOT.

No, Governor Walker, "liberals will try to defend the enormous size of the federal government." We defend individuals rights from a Federal level so that bigots and sexists don't use the phony cry of "state's rights" to prevent a woman from controlling her own body and stopping people of the same sex from getting married.

So speaks the governor who lives in his bubble of like minded others. Here in Wisconsinstan safely insulated from serious questions from the corporate owned press or discussion with the common folk, he litters the state with his press releases touting the wonders of his leadership while the state crumbles beneath us.

I was not sure if I should break out laughing at his self aggrandizement of accomplishments and the current standing Caesar for the Republican party or just shake my head at the utter nonsense he quotes as yet another empty republican suit running what once was a progressive state.  History will not treat Harlequins such as Walker and the act sure isn't amusing or truthful.

Here is Scott Walker making another idiotic bid for President in 2020.

Walker has ruined education and social services in Wisconsin and tanked the Wisconsin economy. He is singing his one-note classic right-wing extremist GOP song: no taxes, no federal control over anything, punish social assistance recipients, Nixon-era war on drugs. We have heard all of this before. Walker totally bombed in 2016. Why is the NY Times giving a platform to this dead-end joker?

What does it mean "Against Protests, Republicans Must Stand Strong"? Does it mean Republicans should ignore that fact that Trump received three million fewer votes than his Democratic component? Does it mean that Republicans should ignore the fact that Republican James Comey abused his power and broke the law to try to install Trump into the presidency? Does it mean that Republicans should ignore Russian interference in the election and Russian collusion with the Trump administration? Does it mean Republicans that Republicans should not take into account that they've heavily (and illegally) gerrymandered the House of Representatives? Does it mean that Republicans should not take into account their many, often successful, attempts to repress legitimate votes? Does it mean that Republicans should forget that they unconstitutionally refused to allow Judge Merrick Garland a hearing?

"Americans were given a choice in November." Yes, and a majority of voters chose Hillary Clinton. An even larger majority did not choose Trump. Stop representing a procedural victory as We the People.

Oh brother.

OK Governor Walker, I have a proposition for you.

In order to further increase corporate profits, a big deal to Republicans I gather, I propose that labor relations be returned to the states. I propose that we return to the system we had before 1860! Yes! This way we wouldn't have to pay people at all and plus, they couldn't quit. Also we would have an endless supply of property - I mean - labor since we would force those women to have babies.

Also, in line with our States Rights proposal, let's talk about women. Women who vote are annoying. They even think they can be president! WORSE those women think they should be able to control their own bodies.

Well, let's just leave it up to the states. Some states might let women vote and some states, well, they might return to their sense and put those females in their place.

Civil rights. Hah, you ask. What about the civil rights of the embattled white Christian male? Let's fix that. We can leave it up to the states whether they think women should vote, labor should be paid, and schools should be segregated (choice!) and mostly, what color people should be allowed to vote.

Indeedy! What could possibly go wrong? It fits in splendidly with your proposition, governor, to allow the citizens of this or that state to just get sick and die already.

After all, who needs a country full of healthy, well-educated, color-blind citizens who think women should be able to vote and workers should get paid?

I grew up in Wisconsin. I was proud of its progressive heritage. I was in Madison on a business trip the night of the election in 2010 where they handed control over to the GOP. I made a comment to a fellow diner at dinner that I think their state made a mistake. He mentioned he thought maybe it was time for a change. Since then, I've watched the state slip toward the bottom in job creation, innovation, education, etc. Yah, I guess it was time for a change. Some change!

Repubs love to scream about State's rights.  The old Democratic South used the same argument to attempt to perpetuate slavery and to secede from the Union. Without a strong Fed gov't to normalize basic rights and existential necessities, the whole thing really falls apart.

Don't worry, Govvie. I'm sure there is some billionaire donor - and from out of state too! - that's willing to flood any state with money which can be used in turn flood the airwaves to "inform" the electorate about those lazy, shiftless - yet incredibly destructive -  protestors. And, after Donny's big tax cut, these civic-minded individuals will undoubtedly have even more money to throw at the "problem". Is this a great country, or what?
